conclusion: The problem involves predicting which container (E or F) liquid will flow into after passing through baffles.
The diagram has four points labeled A, B, C, and D, each with different colored flows representing liquid streams.
The flows interact with angled lines (baffles) and horizontal lines before flowing into containers E or F.
Point A has an orange flow.
Point B has a pink flow.
Point C has a blue flow.
Point D has a yellow flow.
The orange flow from point A is directed downwards and slightly to the left, encountering a baffle that directs it towards container E.
The pink flow from point B is directed downwards towards the center, meeting a baffle that directs it to the right and merging with the blue flow from point C.
The blue flow from point C is directed downwards and to the right, intersecting with the pink flow from point B and heading towards container F.
The yellow flow from point D is directed straight down, hitting a baffle that directs it to the right and heading towards container F.
From observations, the orange flow from point A goes towards container E, while the flows from points B, C, and D merge and go towards container F.
Picture 2 shows flows from A, B, C, and D interacting with baffles and starting to merge.
